[{"wordEn":"use, wear, dress up in finery ","wordAn":"pakay","langSubgroup":"WMP","langName":"Mapun","wordEnLong":"clothes; anything worn (including jewelry)","setnote":"This is a clear Malay loanword in both of its common senses: ‘to use’ and ‘to wear/clothiing, adornment’.  Dempwolff compared the Ngaju Dayak, Malay, Toba Batak and Javanese words given here with Tagalog pákay ‘mission; purpose; intention; aim’, and posited Urindonesisch *pakay ‘to use; to dress up, put on clothing’.  However, the Tagalog word does not appear to be related to the others, and the remaining forms do not justify a reconstruction.
